intro: Teucrium commune var. pseudoaureum, commonly known as golden germander, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright, branching stems covered in fine, greyish hairs. The leaves are lance-shaped, with a slightly serrated margin, and emit a strong, aromatic scent when crushed. Its flowers are small, tubular, and typically violet or blue, arranged in dense clusters at the ends of the stems. This plant thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy and ornamental choice for gardens.
